GOVERNOR DIRECTOR

ST. JOHN'S HOME RESIDENTIAL
2355 KNAPP ST NE,
GRAND RAPIDS, MI, 49505-4411
Re: License #: CI410305582
Investigation #: 2023C0000548
Dear Mr. Harris:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis
Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
** This report contains quoted profanity**
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CI410305582
Licensee Group Organization: DA Blodgett for Children
Licensee Designee: Mary Muliett
Chief Administrator: MAX HARRIS
Agency Name: ST. JOHN'S HOME RESIDENTIAL
Agency Address: 2355 KNAPP ST NE
GRAND RAPIDS, MI 49505-4411
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 03/07/2025
Capacity: 46
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
6/20/2023 9:27 AM Email Other
6/21/2023 9:05 AM Onsite Inspection Unannounced Visit; Interview
6/21/2023 9:21 AM Email Documentation received or sent
6/21/2023 9:28 AM Email Documentation received or sent
6/21/2023 10:08 AM Email Documentation received or sent
6/21/2023 2:25 PM Email Documentation received or sent
7/10/2023 11:10 AM Face to Face Announced Visit; Interview
7/10/2023 1:00 PM Email Documentation received or sent
7/13/2023 11:30 AM Video Conference Pre-Exit Conference
7/17/2023 10:00 AM Video Conference MDHHS Worker – No Findings
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 6/15/23, youth was restrained for 20 minutes by four staff
members. Two staff members restrained at a time and switched
out. One of the staff had left bruises on the youth’s left and right
elbows and shoulders. The bruises were not observed. The youth
took pain medicine after the restraint, and it is unknown if the
youth required medical attention.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Note: Youth A prefers they/them pronouns and will be referred to
as such throughout the report.
Complainant/Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 7/10/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1
was one of the 5 employees involved in the restraint regarding
Youth A. Staff 1 reported on the evening of 6/15/23, the youth had
taken their nighttime medications and were getting ready for bed.
Staff 1 completed a check on Youth A as they were in their room,
and Staff 1 found Youth A upset and crying. Staff 1 asked Youth A
if they wanted to talk, but Youth A refused. Youth A requested
their PRN medication for anxiety, so Staff 1 accommodated the
request. A few minutes later, Youth A was seen in the milieu
walking around slowly. Staff 1 reported Staff 5 asked Youth A why
they were out in the milieu at the time because it was bedtime.
Youth A yelled at Staff 5, said “don’t assume anything”, went to
their room and slammed the door. A couple minutes later, Youth A
exited their room, went into the hallway, and walked out the door
leading outside the home. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 followed Youth
A out of the home. Staff 1 handed the medication room key to
Staff 6 and then left the home to follow Youth A and Staff 2. Staff
1 reported he received a call from Staff 2 stating they were
heading towards the garden/hill area towards the road. Staff 1
stated he called Supervisor while he was walking so she was
aware of what was happening. When Staff 1 arrived at the
garden/hill area, Staff 2 was talking to Youth A, but was not having
2

any success redirecting or de-escalating Youth A. Staff 1 called
for backup. Staff 2 set a boundary for Youth A to not go past a
certain point heading towards the road, but Youth A was not
listening and continued to walk towards the road. Staff 2 asked
Staff 1 to help him initiate a restraint for youth safety. Youth A was
not communicating or responding to both staff at the time, and
was not stopping, so both staff believed the restraint was
necessary to prevent imminent risk of harm. Staff 1 reported they
performed a Reverse Level 1 Aegis Hold. When they were in the
hold, Youth A reported they wanted to throw themselves into the
road, in front of a car, to end their life. Staff 1 reported Supervisor
arrived and assessed the current situation. Staff 1 told Supervisor
he needed a break, so Supervisor switched out with him and
maintained the restraint. Supervisor gave Staff 1 her phone
because Staff 3 was calling, and Staff 1 requested Staff 3 join
them for additional support. During the restraint, Staff 1 reported
Youth A was fighting aggressively to get out of the hold and said
they reported they took notes and practiced how to get out of
holds. Staff 1 reported Youth A was attempting to do backflips to
get out of the hold and bit Staff 1 on the shoulder. The staff started
with a Reverse Level 1 standing hold, but then switched to a
Reverse Level 1 safety ground restraint due to Youth A’s kicking.
When Staff 3 arrived, she switched out with Staff 2. Staff 4 arrived
shortly after, but he only observed, and did not participate in the
restraint. Supervisor asked Youth A if they could start walking
away from the road, towards the garden and Youth A refused.
Supervisor asked Youth A if their intent was to harm themself by
going into the road and Youth A confirmed it was. After about 20
minutes, Youth A noticed their watch was broken and asked to
look for a missing piece. Supervisor offered to look for the watch
while Staff 2 and Staff 1 escorted Youth A back to the house.
Youth A agreed, so Staff 1 and Staff 2 went into a Level 2 hold to
help escort them back to the facility safely. While walking back to
the home, Youth A said multiple times both their arms hurt and
stated Staff 1 held the restraint too tight on the left side. When
they arrived at the house, Staff 1 and Staff 2 were able to end the
restraint because Youth A was no longer fighting or trying to harm
themselves. Youth A was crying and was very emotional, so they
requested to sit outside. Youth A sat outside while Staff 1 and
Staff 2 tried to talk to them. Youth A asked that they be allowed to
cry and communicate what they were feeling but asked the staff
not to respond. Youth A reported this was their first time trying to
kill themself by walking into the road. While outside, Youth A
noticed some bruises on their left arm and blamed Staff 1 for the
bruises. Youth A spent approximately 10-15 minutes outside de-
escalating before wanting to go inside. Upon entering the home,
3

Staff 1 obtained pain medicine from the medication cart for Youth
A while Staff 2 was checking in with Youth A in their bedroom.
Staff 1 reported the restraints were done properly per their training
and the youth’s plan.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 6/21/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Youth A’s Foster Care
Worker was also present for Youth A’s interview per Youth
A’s request. Youth A reported the last few weeks have been
chaos and they feel they need a medication change because they
are very angry all the time for no reason and blow up at others,
even over something small. They feel their anger is rooted in the
depression and is working with their therapist on it. Youth A
reported last week Thursday, they walked out of the house,
walked through the path in the woods and tried to walk into the
road to hurt themself. Youth A reported Staff 1 and Staff 2
followed them through the woods and to the area by the highway.
Youth A reported Staff 2 put them in a restraint because they
reported they wanted to kill themself by walking into the road.
Youth A reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 switched out of the restraint
with Supervisor and Staff 3. Youth A reported Staff 1 and Staff 2
were trying to keep them safe, but they kept fighting to get out of
the restraint by stabbing staff with their nails, kicking all staff who
were restraining, bit Staff 1, and trying to kick and do backflips.
Youth A reported their arms were hurting for about 3 days
afterwards and they had a few bruises on their upper arms and
one by their left elbow. Youth A reported all the bruising on their
lower arms was self-inflicted due to snapping a rubber band on
their arms. Youth A reported none of the staff did anything wrong
during the restraint and did not intentionally hurt them. Youth A
reported they were fighting so hard to get out of the restraint and
they know that’s what caused the bruises. Youth A reported all
staff were holding her appropriately and no one was pushing,
pulling, grabbing unnecessarily, using too much force, hitting, etc.
Youth A reported they did not have any concerns with the restraint
or with any of the staff. Youth A reported they feel safe at the
facility and if anything went wrong or they felt unsafe, they feel
they could talk to any of the staff about it because all the staff are
awesome.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
6/21/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Administrator 1
reported Youth A saw the nurse at the facility the day following the
restraint. Administrator 1 reported the weekend after the restraint
occurred, Youth A was taken to Helen DeVos Children’s Hospital
4

for a check-up due to the bruising and Youth A complaining of
pain in their arms.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on
6/21/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Therapist reported
she saw Youth A on 6/20/23 and Youth A did not talk about the
restraint. Therapist reported she received an email from Youth A’s
Foster Care Worker (FC Worker) on 6/16/23 stating Youth A told
their FC Worker they received bruising from trying to get out of the
restraint and stated they knew no one was intentionally trying to
hurt them. Therapist reported Youth A is vocal about letting staff
know when they are struggling, when they need help and
expressing when they feel they are going to self- harm. Therapist
reviewed the Behavior Observation Record, email from the on-call
clinician the night of the restraint and was able to talk to staff
about what happened the night of the restraint. Therapist reported
staff handled things appropriately based on Youth A’s treatment
plan and safety plan. Therapist reported she created the treatment
plan with Youth A. Therapist stated staff followed Youth A’s lead
with regards to questioning, offering options, etc. Therapist noted
the most important thing staff did during the incident was they
assessed risk before acting and restraining.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 7/10/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported the
evening of 6/15/23, Youth A walked out of the house, and he
followed them. Staff 2 reported he was trying to assess Youth A’s
emotional state by asking questions about Youth A’s intention
(i.e., AWOL, self-harm, simply wanted to walk, etc.), but Youth A
would not respond or talk to Staff 2 at all. As they approached the
garden area, Staff 1 arrived. Youth A continued to try and
approach the road. Staff 2 reported he told Youth A, “I don’t know
what’s happening right now, and I don’t feel safe with you walking
towards the road”. Staff 2 stated he set a boundary for Youth A
and said, “if you walk past this point, we are going to have to
initiate a restraint”. Staff 2 reported he continued to try use verbal
de-escalation tactics with Youth A prior to initiating the restraint.
Staff 2 reported he and Staff 1 updated Youth A the whole time on
what they were going to have to do or what they were doing to
restrain Youth A. After initiating the restraint, Youth A became
upset Staff 1 and Staff 2 stopped them from going into the road
and kept saying “Let me go. I just want to go into the road. I can’t
do this anymore”. Staff 2 stated Supervisor arrived at the scene,
helped with the restraint, and helped coach through the restraint.
Shortly after, Staff 3 also arrived and assisted. Supervisor and
Staff 3 switched in and out of the restraint with Staff 1 and Staff 2.
5

At one point, Youth A bit Staff 1 on the shoulder. Staff 2 reported
they completed a Level 1 standing restraint and then went into a
Level 1 seated safety position due to Youth A fighting to get out of
the restraint. Staff 2 reported Youth A was actively trying to break
the restraint by thrashing their arms, kicking their feet, and trying
to do backflips. Staff 2 felt they did the best they could to keep
Youth A safe and secure in the restraint without injuring Youth A.
Eventually, Youth A became very emotional and sad rather than
angry and aggressive. When Youth A entered this state, they
agreed to walk away from the road and Staff 1 and Staff 2 were
able to escort Youth A back to the house. While walking back,
Staff 2 reported Youth A said “that was the least shitty restraint
I’ve ever seen or been a part of. I thought you guys were going to
hurt me, but you didn’t try to”. Youth A apologized to Staff 1 for
biting him during the restraint and said Staff 1 hurt their arm. Staff
2 reported he couldn’t see any bruises on Youth A’s arms at the
time because it was dark out. Staff 2 reported when they arrived at
the house, Youth A did not want to talk about anything with staff
and just wanted to sit and cry. Staff 2 reported they checked
Youth A for injuries, and there was a mark on Youth A’s upper arm
from the restraint, but he couldn’t remember which arm. Staff 2
reported Youth A had a lot of bruises on their lower arms from
snapping a hair tie as a form of self-harm and Youth A provided
staff with the hair tie when they returned to the home. Staff 2
reported the restraint was done appropriately per their training, no
staff were aggressive with Youth A, and he did not feel anyone
held Youth A too tight.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 7/10/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported she called
Supervisor on the night of 6/15/23, Staff 1 answered the phone,
and he asked her to come to the garden area for assistance with a
restraint. When Staff 3 arrived at the scene, she switched out with
Staff 2 and was completing the Reverse Level 1 standing restraint
with Staff 1. Staff 3 reported Youth A was kicking their legs and
trying to fight to get out of the restraint, so Staff 3 and Staff 1
adjusted to a seated restraint. Staff 3 reported they ended up
adjusting back to a standing restraint and she switched out with
Staff 2. Staff 3 reported she then called Staff 4 and asked him to
come to the garden for additional support. While she made that
call, Staff 3 reported Supervisor was on the phone with Chief
Administrator requesting approval to have the restraint go on
longer due to Youth A still not being safe or calm. Staff 3 reported
Youth A was screaming, calling the staff names, telling the staff
they would kill them, demanding staff let them go and saying they
just wanted to die. Staff 3 reported staff were not aggressive
6

during the restraint, and it was done properly per their training.
Staff 3 reported staff were not escalating the restraint or making
any concerning statements towards Youth A to agitate them. Staff
3 reported Youth A finally calmed down and said they wanted to
get out of the restraint because they were tired and
uncomfortable. Staff 3 reported they all asked Youth A if they were
ready to go back to the house and be safe, to which Youth A
agreed. Staff 3 reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 escorted Youth A back
to the house in a Level 2 restraint to ensure their safety, and when
they arrived back at the house, they disengaged the restraint.
Youth A wanted to sit on the ground and cry by the house but did
not want to engage with staff or have a conversation with staff, so
Staff 1, Staff 2 and Staff 3 stood outside with Youth A and
observed. Staff 3 reported she left once Youth A entered the
house with Staff 1 and Staff 2.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 7/10/23
in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Staff 4 reported he
received a call from Staff 3 stating they needed support at the
garden area, so he went to assist. When he arrived, Staff 4
reported Youth A was sitting in the grass in a seated restraint with
Staff 1 and Staff 2 on either side of them. Staff 4 reported the
restraint was being completed appropriately per their training.
Staff 4 reported Youth A was very upset and seemed to be having
a panic attack as they were upset, short of breath and crying. After
a few minutes, Staff 1, Staff 2 and Youth A stood up and Staff 1
and Staff 2 were able to escort Youth A away from the road.
During the walk back to the house, Staff 4 heard Youth A state
Staff 1 hurt their arm during the restraint because Staff 1 held too
tight. Staff 4 reported he did not see any bruises on Youth A’s
arms at the time. Staff 4 reported he observed part of the restraint,
and it did not look like Staff 1 was holding too tight.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
7/10/23 in conjunction with MDHHS Worker. Supervisor
received a call from Staff 1 stating Youth A walked out of the
house and he and Staff 2 were following Youth A. Supervisor
received another call from Staff 1 requesting support at the garden
area by the road by Dean Lake. When she arrived on scene, Staff
1 and Staff 2 were holding Youth A in a Reverse Level 1 standing
restraint. Due to them being so close to the road and Youth A
being so aggressive trying to get out of the restraint, Supervisor
instructed the staff to go into a seated restraint position for safety.
Then Staff 1 and Staff 2 went back into a standing position
because Youth A continued to fight and was trying to do backflips
to get out of the seated position. When they were standing again,
7

they tried to walk Youth A backwards, while still in the restraint, to
back away from the road. Supervisor reported she told Youth A
they could end the restraint if they calmed down and was willing to
be safe, but Youth A continued to report intent to go into the road
to end their life. Supervisor reported at one point, Youth A stated
their arm hurt, so staff adjusted, and Supervisor assessed Youth A
for injuries, to which she found none. Supervisor reported Youth A
had full mobility in their arm and there were no marks, so she
assessed Youth A’s arm was sore from her fighting so hard to get
out of the restraint. Supervisor reported she called and spoke to
the clinical on call manager to discuss the situation. When Youth
A became calmer, they were able to back away from the road and
then Youth A agreed to go back to the house. Supervisor reported
Staff 1 and Staff 2 escorted Youth A back to the house in a hold
for safety reasons. Supervisor reported she was on the phone and
was walking further behind Staff 1, Staff 2 and Youth A, so she
was not present when they arrived back at the home. Supervisor
reported she checked in on Youth A later that night and Youth A
reported they get manic sometimes and can’t control themself, so
if they cannot find objects to self-harm with, they will go to more
drastic measures. Supervisor reported Youth A had marks and
bruises up and down their forearms from snapping a rubber band
on their forearm for self-harm. Supervisor also noticed a bruise on
Youth A’s shoulder but couldn’t remember which arm. Supervisor
reported the restraint happened properly, per their training.
Supervisor noted they were constantly assessing and trying to de-
escalate the situation. Supervisor stated staff were even mindful of
how much time they were in the restraint and followed appropriate
steps to get approval to go past the recommended or allowed
timeframes. Supervisor reported staff were not aggressive with
Youth A and did nothing to escalate the situation.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Incident Report #156930205 from incident on 6/15/23 was
consistent with Staff 1’s interview.
• D.A. Blodgett St. John’s Restrictive Intervention Procedures
(rev. 8/2022) outlines when and how restrictive measures
are to be utilized. Only AEGIS System Model is allowed to
be used. Restrictive measures are only to be used in
emergency situations and as a last resort when an
event/action is likely to result in imminent, seriously
physical harm and/or the loss of life, and less restrictive
measures have been ineffective. Continuous restrictive
intervention may not exceed 15 minutes without approval.
8

• D.A. Blodgett St. John’s Psychiatric Assessment for Youth
A dated 5/24/23. Youth A is diagnosed with Scoliosis,
Stage 2 kidney disease (right kidney), Hyperlipidemia,
PTSD, Major Depressive Disorder Recurrent Moderate and
ADHD Combined Presentation. Youth A is prescribed
medications and is compliant with taking them.
• Helen DeVos discharge paperwork for Youth A dated
6/17/23 stating Youth A was seen for bruising. Youth A
stated she felt safe when she was restrained, and staff
completed a restraint to prevent her from harming herself.
Youth A had one bruise on each arm and on one underarm
from the restraint. Youth A reported most of the bruising on
her arms is from repeatedly snapping rubber bands on her
arm. Youth A denied extremity pain and continued with full
active range of motion without pain. Hospital assessed
Youth A to be healthy and discharged without concerns.
Pictures of the bruising were attached to the paperwork.
• Medical Note from Medical Services Coordinator at D.A.
Blodgett St. John’s dated 6/16/23 states Nurse met with
Youth A. Youth A reported to Nurse they “felt bad because
they bit Staff 1, and they like him, and they were poking
staff with their nails too.” Nurse assessed Youth A for
bruising (right & left underarm dime-size and one by Youth
A’s left elbow which was small and purple). Youth A
reported feeling safe and denied staff purposely causing
harm.
• D.A. Blodgett St. John’s Safety Plan dated 5/15/23
completed by Therapist regarding Youth A’s self-harm.
Staff are to complete daily check-ins with Youth A to gauge
current mental state so any changes can be reported to
therapist or on call clinician. Adults will check on Youth A
when they are isolating in their room and adults should
engage Youth A in conversation. Youth A’s known triggers
and coping skills are outlined. Staff should monitor Youth
A’s behaviors for self-harm. Staff should attempt to ask
questions about their thoughts and feelings to gather
information; report to therapist or on call clinician to
determine whether a status or heightened supervision is
necessary. Staff should monitor for triggers and warning
signs and implement interventions.
• Residential Initial Services Plan for Youth A dated 4/29/23
states non-physical intervention will be provided according
9

to the verbal de-escalation techniques established by
AEGIS. Any physical intervention required will be provided
according to AEGIS.
• Staff 1 does not have any discipline in his employee file.
Staff 1 completed AEGIS training on 9/8/22 and 11/3/22.
Staff 1 completed AEGIS Benevolent Holding Skills
Residential Team Meeting Trainings on 3/2/23 and 4/20/23.
• Staff 2 does not have any discipline in his employee file.
Staff 2 completed AEGIS training on 2/8/22, 2/9/22, 2/24/22
and 11/17/22. Staff 2 completed AEGIS Benevolent
Holding Skills Residential Team Meeting Trainings on
4/28/22, 7/28/22, 9/8/22, 3/2/23 and 4/20/23.
• Staff 3 has one disciplinary record in her employee file
unrelated to this investigation. Staff 3 completed AEGIS
training on 8/17/22 and 11/3/22. Staff 3 completed AEGIS
Benevolent Holding Skills Residential Team Meeting
Trainings on 9/8/22 and 3/2/23.
• Staff 4 does not have any discipline in his employee file.
Staff 4 completed AEGIS training on 3/8/22, 3/9/22 and
11/3/22. Staff 4 completed AEGIS Benevolent Holding
Skills Residential Team Meeting Trainings on 4/28/22,
9/8/22 and 4/20/23.
• Supervisor does not have any discipline in her employee
file. Supervisor completed AEGIS training on 9/15/21,
2/24/22 and 11/17/22. Supervisor completed AEGIS
Benevolent Holding Skills Residential Team Meeting
Trainings on 9/30/21, 11/11/21, 4/28/22, 7/28/22, 9/8/22,
3/2/23 and 4/20/23.
Analysis Based on interviews conducted and documentation reviewed, this
violation is not established. Youth A and all employees
interviewed about the restraint state the restraint was completed
to keep Youth A safe and was conducted properly. Youth A
reported staff did not purposely harm them and reported they
received the bruises due to fighting so hard to get out of the
restraint. Therapist reported staff followed Youth A’s treatment
plan when conducting the restraint.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
10

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
July 17, 2023
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 24, 2023
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
11
